entry.title: Tirthan Valley – Nature Weekend Getaway
entry.content:
Tirthan Valley is the most untouched valleys of Himachal Pradesh. Tirthan Valley is popular for its trout fishing which is considered a delicacy in the valley as well as amongst tourists. Tirthan Valley also homes the Great Himalayan National Park, a UNESCO world heritage site with many species native to the Indian Himalayas. Tirthan River flows through the valley which merges with Beas and Satluj on either ends of the valley. This trip will entail a complete local and sustainable experience along with engaging on the significance of biodiversity in the valley.

Tour Details:

No. of Travel Days:   2 nights/ 3 Days

Best Season: Jan- Dec

Max. Altitude: 3200m

Accommodation: Homestays

Transportation: MUVs

Price Design:

Couple Price (2-3): 10,499 INR

Group Price (4-8): 8,999

Detailed Itinerary

Day 1:

Arrive at Gurshaini

Arrive at Gurshaini, Tirthan Valley. Transfers will be arranged from Aut direct buses are available at Aut, Stay will be arranged at a homestay in Gurshaini for the night. A day hike till Nagini water fall is the activity planned for the day.

 Day 2:

Jalori Pass/Day Hike to GHNP

Wake up in the morning, have breakfast, drive to Jalori Pass. Trek and Hiking around the Pass to get views of Pir Panjal Range and then 5km oneway Trek to Saryosal Lake from Jalori Pass. The trails goes through dense deodar forests which takes about 90 mins one way emerging at the beautiful lake, lunch can be taken at dhabas. Another option is to take a day hike to Great Himalayan National Park, this is a 16km fairly easy walk through the National Park. We will return to the homestays followed by dinner at the homestay.

 Day 3:

Relax and Depart:

Relaxing day for walks or just chai’s at the homestay. Drop back to Auth by early evening.

We love living in outdoors and the adrenaline, we also believe that it is truly the greatest gift of God, the beauty and magic outdoors, hence the need to respect it. We are laying very basic and easy to do guidelines for the same with the motive of leaving minimum footprint, preserving the flora, fauna, biodiversity and ecology of the region along with coming close to local communities and culture of the region. We truly believe that you will help us in initiating this and become an Eco-Traveler, if not already one.

 

A little on what Ecotourism exactly is

A dictionary defines it as "tourism directed towards unspoilt natural environments and intended to support conservation efforts". In addition, Eco-Traveler believes in supporting, protection and at the same time experiencing local culture and heritage. Tourism results in social, as well as environmental impacts, and a responsible tourist needs to be aware of this.

 

Here is how you can help

Carrying your own water bottle, cups, plates and filling water from natural resource, drinking locally brewed products served in glass or recyclable materials.

entry.title: Life in Sub-Zero – Winter Culture Trail –Spiti Valley
entry.content:
Spiti Valley is a desert mountain valley located high in the Himalaya Mountains in the north-eastern part of the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. The name "Spiti" means "The Middle Land", i.e. the land between Tibet and India. A raw and untouched landscape that gives you a real off-road experience and a feeling of being on the roof of the world. This is an unqiue experience to take you through life in Spiti in winters.

Tour Details:

No. of Travel Days: 7 nights/ 8 Days

Best Season: Jan – Mid April

Max. Altitude: 4500 m

Accommodation: Hotels, Village Home Stays

Transportation: MUV

Price Design:

Couple Price PP: 75,000 INR

3 Persons: 42,000 INR

Group Price (4 or above): 35,000 INR

Note: We don't do groups bigger than 8 people to ensure quality experience and minimum tourist footprint

Detailed Itinerary

 Day 1:

Arrival in Shimla

Being the first day of the rough roadtrip, we keep it light and easy. We arrive to the beautiful Queen of Hills – Shimla and Check-in. Today is a relaxing day. A debrief of the tour will be shared in the evening.

 Day 2: Shimla – Kalpa

We start the day early in the morning towards Kalpa. Kalpa is a tiny gem Kinnaur surrounded by Kinner Kailash Ranges. We will rest up in the hotel in Kalpa in the evening to get ready for the next day.

 Day 3: Kalpa – Nako – Tabo

The drive is along Spiti through the arid landscape to reach Nako, a small village in Kinnaur region of Himachal. Nako is famous for its magnificent Nako Lake (3661m) a small clear water lake. From Nako we leave for a long journey to Tabo, which is the oldest monastery of Buddhist times. Tabo houses a historic monastery from 996 A.D. and the monastery is believed to be of great historical significance. Stay will be organized in a local homestay with local savories served.

 Day 4: Tabo - Gyu –– Kaza

The next day the journey to one of the most beautiful places in Spiti. We would also visit the famous monastery of Gyu, the one that preserves the mummy of a monk. Dhankar overlooks the amalgam of two very beautiful rivers – Pin and Spiti, curling up and meeting. It’s has famous for its monastery which is quite old but has stood the test of time. Night stay will be organized in a local homestay at Kaza with local savories served.

 Day 5 Rest Day at Kaza

Being on the road in cold climate and high altitudes can get hectic, rest is necessary. Today we keep a light day singing local songs and enjoying the heat of the tandoor in Kaza.

 Day 6: Kaza – Key – Kibber – Dhankar

We begin the next day early from Kaza, we drive to Key monastery followed by Kibber, Today has been planned to be a bit challenging and also giving a real picture of how Spitians survive in winters. The last stop we make is to Dhankar and stay there in an authentic homestay seeing how they survive. From fuel to heat to food to untold stories.

 Day 7: Dhankar - Kalpa

Time to return back to base, we start early morning from Dhankar towards Kalpa.

 Day 8: Kalpa - Shimla

An overnight Journey from Manali to Delhi by road.

entry.content:
Spiti Valley is a desert mountain valley located high in the Himalaya Mountains in the north-eastern part of the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. The name "Spiti" means "The Middle Land", i.e. the land between Tibet and India. A raw and untouched landscape that gives you a real off-road experience and a feeling of being on the roof of the world.

Best Season: July - Sept

Max. Altitude: 4500 m

Accommodation: Hotels, Village Home Stays and Camps

Transportation: MUVs, Motor Bikes

Price Design:

 Couple Price 2 pax: 45000 INR

Group Price (4 and above): 30000 INR

Note: We don't do groups bigger than 8 people to ensure quality experience and minimum tourist footprint

 

Detailed Itinerary

 Day 1:

Arrival Jibhi/Shoja

Being the first day of the rough roadtrip, we keep it light and easy. We arrive to the beautiful Sainj valley, we make our stay at Jibhi in a very cozy homestay. One can walk around there are many hiking spots around Jibhi. A debrief of the tour will be shared in the evening.

 Day 2: Jibhi - Sangla

The drive from Jibhi to Sangla is a day long one, we would be covering a distance of 210 kms, we will start early in the morning. Sangla Valley homes Chitkul which is the last village on the Indo-Tibetan border. One gets visuals of one of the most spectular sights of the higher Himalayas. We stay the night at Chitkul.

 Day 3: Sangla - Kalpa – Nako – Tabo

We start the day early in the morning towards Kalpa. The drive is along Spiti through the arid landscape to reach Nako, a small village in Kinnaur region of Himachal. Nako is famous for its magnificent Nako Lake (3661m) a small clear water lake. From Nako we leave for a long journey to Tabo, which is the oldest monastery of Buddhist times. Tabo houses a historic monastery from 996 A.D. and the monastery is believed to be of great historical significance. Stay will be organized in a local homestay with local savories served.

 Day 4: Tabo - Gyu – Pin Valley – Dhankar

The next day the journey to one of the most beautiful places in Spiti –Pin Valley, along the magnificent Spiti River which just kept growing in beauty. We would also visit the famous monastery of Gyu, the one that preserves the mummy of a monk. We would do a day trip to Mudh, Pin Valley and come back to Dhankar. Dhankar overlooks the amalgam of two very beautiful rivers – Pin and Spiti, curling up and meeting. It’s has famous for its monastery which is quite old but has stood the test of time. Dhankar also houses a high altitude lake (4270m) which can be accessed by a small trek of 2kms.  The lake is grand and the hike is highly rewarding. Pin Valley National Park is frequently visited by wildlife enthusiast looking to catch a glimpse of elusive snow leopard. If time permits one can stay another day to see the lake or the fitter can see it the same evening or next morning. Night stay will be organized in a local homestay with local savories served.

 From Dhankar, we head towards Kaza and from Kaza we make a visit to the oldest Monasteries and the Highest Villages of the Himalayan Terrain over a period of two days. One night stay will be in Kaza and the other in a local homestay in Langza/Komic.

 Day 5 Dhankar – Lalung – Demul – Komic – Langza – Kaza:

From Dhankar, we head towards Kaza and from Kaza we make a visit to the oldest Monasteries and the Highest Villages of the Himalayan Terrain over a period of two days. Komic is the world highest village at an altitude of 4580 mts. We conclude the day at Kaza.

 Day 6: Kaza – Key – Kibber – Chicham

We begin the next day early from Kaza, we drive to Key monastery followed by Kibber, and we drive to Gyate and Tashigang. Lastly we take a very exciting cable car to go to Chicham. We spend the night at kibber

 

Day 7: Kibber - Chandratal

Today is a long drive again, we start the day early, we visit the very famous Chandratal Lake, spend which will take us about 3 hours to reach from Kibber, post which we head back to Manali and reach Manali by evening.

 

Day 8: Chandratal - Manali

An overnight Journey from Manali to Delhi by road.

entry.title: Trace the Snow Leopard – Spiti Valley
entry.content:
Snow leopard is generally found in Kibber wildlife Sanctuary and Pin valley National park of Spiti Valley. Snow leopard has been spotted by locals around Lippa - Asrang Sanctuary. Kibber wildlife sanctuary is the home of snow leopards, though we must stress that the Snow Leopard remains one of the most elusive animals on the planet, and sightings are not guaranteed. Other animals we have a chance of seeing are the Bharal (Blue Sheep) and Ibex.

No. of Travel Days:  7 nights/ 8 Days

Best Season: Jan - March

Max. Altitude: 4500 m

Accommodation: Homestays

Transportation: MUVs

4 Persons or more: 42,000

Note: We don't do groups bigger than 8 people to ensure quality experience and minimum tourist footprint

 

Detailed Itinerary

 Day 01: Shimla to Rekong Peo:

One arrives to Shimla from Delhi, an overnight Journey. After arriving at Shimla one can directly head towards RekongPeo.  One gets close view of journey was along the river Satluj.  Stay will be organized in a local homestay with local savories served. The day is long and the roads are treacherous.

 Day 02: Rekong Peo to Kaza:

We start next day early morning from Rekong Peo towards Kibber, this is a long day but the snow valleys will be breathtaking hence you will not feel the distance. We will reach Kaza by evening. Stay will be in a homestay.

 Day 03: Acclimitisation

Acclimatization in Kaza with some local sight seeing

 Day 04: Snow Leopard Sighting - Kibber

The time for adventure begins, we drive to Kibber and start walking towards the slopes early morning, packed lunch will be provided, we spend the day sighting and return to the homestay by the evening at Kibber.

 Day 05: Snow Leopard Sighting – Kibber

On this day we walk towards different slopes, we observe the paw marks of the enigmatic snow leopard to be able to sight one. We start walking towards the slopes early morning, packed lunch will be provided, and we spend the day sighting and return to the homestay by the evening at Kibber.

 Day 06: Snow Leopard Sighting – Kibber/Return to Kaza

The last day for sighting we start pre sunrise and spend the day on the silent mountain sides, packed lunch will be provided, we spend the day sighting and return to the homestay by the evening at Kaza.

 Day 7: Kaza – Rekong Peo:

We start our journey early morning to reach Rekong Peo by evening

.Day 8: Rekong Peo - Shimla

The last day of the journey, you will be dropped back to Shimla by evening.

entry.title: The Great White Rann – Landscape and Culture
entry.content:
Kachchh, India’s Wild West, is a geographic phenomenon. The flat, tortoise-shaped land (kachbo means tortoise in Gujarati), edged by the Gulf of Kachchh and Great and Little Ranns, is a seasonal island. During the dry season, the Ranns are vast expanses of hard, dried mud. Come the monsoon, they’re flooded first by seawater, then by fresh river water. The salt in the soil makes the low-lying marsh area almost completely barren. Only on scattered ‘islands’ above the salt level is coarse grass which provides fodder for the region’s wildlife.

Tour Details:

No. of Travel Days:  2 nights/ 3 Days

Best Season: Nov- March

Max. Altitude: Sea Level

Accommodation: Village Homestays

Transportation: MUVs

Price Design:

Ahmedabad – Ahmedabad

Couple Price: 22,500, Group Price: 15,250

 

Detailed Itinerary

 Day 01: Pick up from Ahmedabad/Bhuj drive to Kachch

 The road distance from Ahmedabad to Kachch is 400 odd kms which is covered in about 6-7 hours’ time. The drive from Bhuj to Kachch is a shorter one which takes about 2 hours. The stay will be at a village homestay at the heart of the Great Rann of Kachch where we will give you an experience of culture and handicrafts through local cusines.

 

Day 02: Kala Dunger and the White Rann + Rannutsav

 After having a good tight sleep, is the villages of Kachch we start the day with a walk through of the local handicrafts and artisans. Post breakfast we drive to Kala Dunger, the black hill of Gujrat which is about an hour drive from Kachch and return from there post lunch to finally enjoy the sunset at the Great White Rann. Post the sunset we take you to the Rannutsav and then back to the Village stay for dinner.

 Day 03: Last visit to the White Rann, drive back to Ahmedabad/Bhuj:

Post an early breakfast we drive once again to the White Rann to see its morning glory and then drive and drop back to Ahmedabad/Bhuj

entry.title: Manali – Leh – High Road and Culture Tour
entry.content:
This is the road trip that is the dream of every off beat traveler seeking views of breathtaking landscapes, a unique out of the world culture and a real life time extreme adventure experience. This is a road trip is not for the faint hearted as it is along the high altitude passes of the world. The air is thin and the climate is extreme, however it’s an adventure worth taking. Marked as one of the most dangerous highways of the world, you are in for a trip of a lifetime. A Mecca for bikers across the world.

Tour Details:

No. of Travel Days: 9 nights/ 10 Days

Best Season: July - Sept

Max. Altitude: 4500 m

Accommodation: Hotels, Village Home Stays and Camps

Transportation: MUVs, Motor Bikes

Price Design:

Couple Price: INR 55000 INR

Group Price: INR 30000 INR

 

Note: We don't to groups bigger than 8 pax for experience and minimum tourist footprint

Detailed Itinerary

 Day 1 - Manali

Located on the banks of Beas River Valley, Manali is the queen of all hesitations in India rather in the world. It is a paradisiacal place and one of the top tourist spots in the world. Breathtaking landscape consisting of meandering streams, snowcapped peaks, fruit orchards and ancient temples are highlights of this picturesque town during the Manali to Leh road trip. You will arrive to Manali during the day, stay will be arranged with breakfast included, and one can spend the day relaxing in their lodge or visiting the local signature spots like Vashisht, Hadimba Temple, Van Vihar etc.

 Day 2 - Sarchu (4290 m)

We leave for Sarchu earlier in the morning. On the Manali to Leh road trip, one gets spectacular and panoramic views from the Rohtang Pass. Located 51km from Manali, at an altitude of 3900m, it is a route that leads to places such as Pangi, Lahaul Spiti and Leh. You get views of beautiful snow-capped peaks and glaciers from here. It is in this vicinity that the Chandra River flows too. After crossing Rohtang the real thrill begins, the next stops are Keylong, Jispa and finally the first high altitude pass, Baralachhla (4890 m), we cross the J&K border after Barachhla and camp the night at Sarchu, a dry highland.

 Day 3 - (3500 m) - Leh

Leh, a high-desert city in the Himalayas, is the capital of the Ladakh region in northern India’s Jammu and Kashmir state. Originally a stop for trading caravans, Leh is now known for its Buddhist sites and several trekking destinations. We will rest today after 2 days of treacherous and adventures road trip. Evening Visit to Shanti Stupa. Night Stay at homestay in Leh.

 Day 4. Moonscapes in Lamayuru

Visit Phayang Monastery , Liker , and Lamayuru. – Home stay at Lamayuru.

[Home stay and local meal prepared by the lady of the house]

 Day 5.History and Culture 

Drive to Rezong Nunury , Alchi Monastery and Saspol Caves [See 15th Century wall panting]. 

(Home stay at Saboo village, Local meal) -  Homestay/ Guest house in Saboo

 Day 6.Prayers, Peace and Relaxation

Saboo to Pangong Lake : Visit Thiksey Monastery Morning (5:30 am assembly) and later visit Hemis Monastery and proceed to Pangong lake.  

[Accommodation at  by the Pangong Lake.]  home stay move to tangste village.

Day 7.Village Exploration 

Pangong to Nubra valley , en-route visit Tangtse  Monastery. In the evening visit Visit sand dune in Hunder and witness double hump Camel. 

[ Home stay at village Nubra and local meal or MoMos with soup.)  Home stay at Hundar village.

 Day 8. Day Excursion to Turtuk village

 After breakfast drive to turtuk (  Approx 65 km ) Home stay at Hundar village.

Day 9. World highest Motorable 

Nubra valley to Leh, vai Khardong La [Pass] . 5359m | 

:  Diskit Monastery and back to Leh (Guest House)

  Day 10. Departure Home

      Transfer to Leh Airport.

 

Trip Guidelines

 Hello Fellow Travelers,

Thank you for choosing Eco-Traveler, at the offset we are extremely excited and totally looking forward to host a memorable trip for you. We love living in outdoors and the adrenaline, we also believe that it is truly the greatest gift of God, the beauty and magic outdoors, hence the need to respect it. We are laying very basic and easy to do guidelines for the same with the motive of leaving minimum footprint, preserving the flora, fauna, biodiversity and ecology of the region along with coming close to local communities and culture of the region. We truly believe that you will help us in initiating this and become an Eco-Traveler, if not already one.

 

A little on what Ecotourism exactly is

A dictionary defines it as "tourism directed towards unspoilt natural environments and intended to support conservation efforts". In addition, Eco-Traveler believes in supporting, protection and at the same time experiencing local culture and heritage. Tourism results in social, as well as environmental impacts, and a responsible tourist needs to be aware of this.

 

Here is how you can help

Carrying your own water bottle, cups, plates and filling water from natural resource, drinking locally brewed products served in glass or recyclable materials.

Using litter bins to trash items that do not decompose, minimum use of purchases packed in plastic, carry a waste bag for your personal non-biodegradable waste.

Enjoying watching the biodiversity of the geography, not playing loud music or being loud, when we go outdoors, we are borrowing home of animals and birds, it’s our responsibility to ensure they are not disturbed.

Purchasing locally produced items- from handicrafts to breweries to savories

Keeping minimum carbon footprint and nil plastic footprints on the trail through not burning plastic or wood.

 

Things an Eco-Traveler carries

Apart from personal clothing and toiletries following items need to be carried in order to make this do it yourself and minimum footprint trek and also for your personal convenience-

Carry your own water bottle, tea up and a tiffin box for packing lunch, instead of using disposable packing material. Water bottle with filters are available, however the natural resources are clean and pristine. It’s good to carry dry fruits and nuts for personal use.

Carry a day bag pack, we will provide potters for those need it, however only essentials can be carried for an overnight trek in a day pack.

A waste bag to collect waste on the way in your day pack.

 

Travel light and easy to enjoy the true essence of backpacking!

  • Pick up from Manali and drop at Leh
  • One night stay in Manali
  • All meals: breakfast, dinner during in village homestays and camps
  • Area Permit & TIMS Cards.
  • All transportation, tourist service charge, VAT and Office Service charge

entry.title: An Adventurous Weekend Getaway to Chandratal
entry.content:
Chandratal is a high altitude sweet water lake in the highlands of Spiti, located at a height of 14500 ft. The source is underground water and it is the most mesmerizing sight you will come across in your life.

Tour Details:

No. of Travel Days:  3 nights/ 4 Days

Best Season: July - Sept

Max. Altitude: 5000 m

Accommodation: Homestays, Camps

Transportation: MUVs

Price Design:

2-4 persons: 13,500

5-9 persons: INR 8,500

Day 1 Manali

Arrive at Manali in the morning, stay will be arranged in a country side guest house in Old Manali. Spend the day Relaxing and local sight-seeing in Manali. One can visit Hadimba temple, Vashisht or just take it easy in café’s in Old Manali.

 

Day 2: Manali to Kunzum Pass Via Rohtang Pass

The day will begin early in the road, Manali to Kunzum Pass is about a 6 hour drive with constant change in landscape and altitude. Drinking a lot of water is the key to remain healthy. We will cross Chhatru and have Lunch at the very famous Chandra Dhaba in Batal run by the very famous Chacha and Chachi who were recognized by the Govt of India for saving lives of 110 people in 2010 during Uttarakhand floods.Trek: Our campsite for the night is about 11 kms from Batal, however there is a lesser known trek from Kunzum Pass to Chandratal which is about 13kms (4-5 hours) for the braver and fitter one’s. You will have a choice between driving there or trekking. We reach the camp by early evening, acclimatize and take rest

 

Day 3: Chandratal Circle

We spent the whole of next day from morning till early evening watching different shades of the magical and pristine Chandratal Lake. It changes shades from being mirror to turning blue as the suns position and direction of the wind changes. The circle is about 4 kms walk offering angles. A paradise for photographers. We come back to campsite and night and Make Merry.

 

Day 4: Chandratal - Manali

We leave early morning for Manali and arrive by post noon, one can take a bus back to Delhi the same evening
